description: From Late Latin plēthōra, from Ancient Greek πληθώρη (plēthṓrē, “fullness, satiety”), from πλήθω (plḗthō, “to be full”) +‎ -η (-ē, nominal suffix).

nouns.description: plethora (countable and uncountable, plural plethorae or plethoras)

entries.meaning: (usually followed by of) An excessive amount or number; an abundance.
examples: The menu offers a plethora of cuisines from around the world.

entries.meaning: (medicine) Excess of blood in the skin, especially in the face and especially chronically.
examples: [Y]our Character at Present is like a Person in a Plethora, absolutely dying of too much Health—
